p: Interestingly, in contrast to our findings, recent studies by Todd et al. [ 64, 65] aiming to elucidate observed enhanced mortality during polymicrobial C. albicans and S. aureus intra-abdominal infection, identified C. albicans-mediated increase in S. aureus secreted alpha- and delta-toxins during polymicrobial infection. Although these factors are important virulence factors in S. aureus crucial to its ability to cause systemic and disseminated infections, down-regulation of these factors might contribute to survival, persistence, and growth in a biofilm environment, as was seen in our biofilm infection model. Nevertheless, the contrasting regulation of S. aureus exotoxins mediated by C. albicans between the two animal models highlights the complex interactions between these two pathogens, and support the notion of niche-specific augmented pathogenesis in a co-infected host.
